author: R Ramabhadran Pillai
text:
The recent death of a boy in Alappuzha due to amoebic encephalitis is a pointer to the gravity of the problems generated by polluted water bodies across Kerala. The incident was the first of its kind in the State, said Jamuna Varghese, Deputy District Medical Officer, Alappuzha.

The death, due to attack on the brain of the victim by the disease-causing organism, was classified in the “rarest of the rare” category.

What is scary is that the circumstances that led to the infection still prevail.

World over, only 300 deaths had occurred, Dr. Varghese told The Hindu . Yet, the medical community should be vigilant against the recurrence of the disease.

The amoeba invades the nervous system through the nasal tissues when water enters nasal cavity during activities such as swimming and bathing. It migrates to the brain and causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), according to medical experts.

The victim had taken a swim in the contaminated canal water at Pallathuruthy here.

The district medical authorities cautioned people against making use of the water in the canal.

Warm polluted water in canals or ponds is congenial to the growth of the disease-causing organism.

A boy who went for a swim in a canal in Alappuzha died of amoebic encephalitis
title: Kerala’s water bodies turn infectious
